posts.name:
Dr. Birendra Singh
Dr. Birendra Singh
posts.content:
Main reasons of employee leaving job based on my experience,

‚Ä¢ Lack of growth opportunities, working in same role
‚Ä¢ Overworking with out support of Seniors
‚Ä¢ Achievements are unnoticed, and partiality in rewards
‚Ä¢ Trust, if broken from both the sides
‚Ä¢ Uncompetitive compensation
‚Ä¢ Leadership disconnect
‚Ä¢ Promotion to non-performers
‚Ä¢ Feeling undervalued compared to industry peers
‚Ä¢ When personal and organizational values clash

Mental resignation happens much before actual resignation?

posts.name:
Sumit Mishra
Sumit Mishra
posts.content:
3 Rivers Ganga, Yamuna and Saraswati

3 Planets/ Stars Sun, and Jupiter

Today marks the beginning of the largest festival on Earth - the Mahakumbh in Prayagraj, where millions of devotees will gather to take a holy dip in the confluence of the Ganga, Yamuna, and Saraswati rivers.

The dedication and devotion of these individuals, braving the cold weather, is truly inspiring and a testament to the deep cultural roots of our heritage.

Let us all align ourselves with this auspicious occasion and embrace the spirit of unity and faith.

posts.content:
Real or AI?

I've noticed this photo going around on Facebook. 

People are inspired and amazed by the design.

However, I got a feeling this is simply AI generated.

As there are too many things that wouldn't make sense!

What do you think?

For me, sink makes no sense, also the mirror on the wall, that looks like a window...

What else?

Source: Unknown

posts.name:
Tony Jamous
Tony Jamous
posts.content:
BREAKING: Washington Post employees ordered back to the office 5 days a week!

Let‚Äôs not forget Jeff Bezos, who owns The Post, sent a brutal warning to Amazon employees a few months ago about the need to return to office.

I wouldn‚Äôt say I‚Äôm surprised, but I am disappointed that we're still talking about this.

All managers back by February 3rd. Everyone else by June.

‚ÄúWe are really good when we are working together in person,‚Äù said Lewis, CEO of the post.

As the CEO of a large remote company, I know this for a fact:

Remote work doesn‚Äôt mean unproductive.

‚Üí It means flexibility and freedom.

For years, I worked in an office.

I know how it feels when you don‚Äôt need to be there but you have to be there.

I know about the missed birthdays, the missed moments and the time that goes by.

Late-night work sessions, creative meetings while on a walk, or even the kitchen table.

‚Üí It works for me and it works for my team.

The real issue here?

‚Üí  The lack of trust in your employees to manage their own time.

We should be trusting our teams, not chaining them to office desks.

Are we really still stuck in this conversation in 2025?

comments.commentText:
As a manager, if you believe that forcing employees back into the office are going to make your teams more productive, YOU are part of the problem. 

Managers need to learn to MANAGE their teams vs forcing them into antiquated thought processes. 

Jobs should be objective driven in where employees understand their expectations and then are given the trust and flexibility to execute those according to agreed upon KPI‚Äôs.

If you want professionals working for you, treat them as such.
Mike Trahan, CSP Agree 100%. Blindly forcing teams back to the office fulltime shows a lack of data driven decision making and lack of true leadership!

It has nothing to do with lack of trust‚Ä¶

The simple fact is that when you have people in a room working together it creates a level of synergism that otherwise would not happen. 

When I‚Äôm in the office with colleagues some of our ‚Äúwater cooler‚Äù conversations are far more impactful than any Zoom/Teams/Google Meet meetings.

I‚Äôm not saying I agree with going back to the office 5 days a week because I don‚Äôt. Having the flexibility to work remotely empowers people and gives them the ability to be the best version of themselves.

PLEASE STOP BERATING CEOs BECAUSE THEY WANT PEOPLE BACK IN OFFICE. THERES A REASON WHY FOUNDERS THAT ‚ÄúLIVED‚Äù AT THE OFFICE ARE SO SUCCESSFUL. THEY ARE CONNECTED WITH THE BUSINESS.

Channing Tipton I'll avoid matching your all-caps meltdown but anyone who expects employees to go to an office needs to walk the walk and show up themselves. "Rules for thee, not for me" is a guaranteed way to destroy morale

posts.name:
Chris James L.
Chris James L.

James Murphy
James Murphy
posts.content:
Sigh. The anti-TDD movement (if we can call it that) is quite tiresome.

Asking what examples of enterprise software TDD logic is used for is like asking which type of medium you are going to use for your art.

It can be any kind of business rule not just a simple boolean. I couldn‚Äôt tell you whether X or Y is the business rule we‚Äôre talking about.

I was recently asked.

‚ÄúDo I realise the difference between TDD and automated testing‚Äù

I‚Äôve been developing for 20 years. I first was taught TDD practices 14 years ago. We used it exclusively to build a warehouse management solution forand I‚Äôve used the practise successfully at numerous major FTSE 100 orgs.

THG company listed for $7 billion on the London Stock Exchange when it IPO‚Äôd. So clearly it works. Many businesses have been built off the back of TDD best practices. Many have won awards.

I‚Äôve taught TDD first principles to room of 30-40 software engineers at the BBC and Booking and it‚Äôs a practise that needs to be honed just like any other.

No one is stopping you from designing software up front. No one is stopping you from building prototypes but then reverting to TDD when you understand the design means you can reduce bloat and simplify solutions. You only write the code you need and know regressions are covered.

If you write tests afterwards how do you know you won‚Äôt get false positives? How do you know your bugs are covered? How do you refactor complex software safely without lots of manual testing if there are holes that aren‚Äôt covered?

Millions of software engineers successfully use TDD every day.

Anti-TDD advocates are basically saying that because they don‚Äôt like hammers and it doesn‚Äôt work for them, other engineers shouldn‚Äôt use hammers. TDD is a paradigm and approach that works for some software engineers, helps them build more rigour into the software code they write.

I can‚Äôt count how many times tests have caught me in complex refactors. Tests that should in no way have failed but did.

‚ÄúTo err is human‚Äù

I don‚Äôt understand the argument that if you‚Äôre some god engineer then you don‚Äôt need tests or to write tests first. Great for you - God engineer but most people aren‚Äôt superhuman. Most engineers make mistakes and we use TDD as an approach to make us better at the craft.

I get that some people don‚Äôt enjoy TDD but I find this attitude a little negative and not particularly inclusive to anyone aside from ‚Äúelite‚Äù programmers. Use what works for your team and you should absolutely try TDD and persevere with it until you‚Äôve had a good try.

We should be pulling our fellow engineers up, not sneering at them because they use tools and practises that we don‚Äôt agree with or discouraging them because of our own internal biases. That‚Äôs the whole point of teams, to work together and to experiment.

comments.commentText: TDD is a net negative unless you have done significant design and work with only A players. The rewriting of tests is a heavy burden and is killer when you have a variation of skill.

Selva Rasappah  that's why I always strongly advise against spies and assertions unless there are side effects. If the side effects and output are what you expect to see, then it doesn't matter what the actual code is doing.

posts.name:
Jennifer Bleam, Sales Sherpa
Jennifer Bleam, Sales Sherpa
posts.content:
How to Document a Winning Sales Call
 
Most salespeople think the call ends when they hang up. But the real magic happens in the debrief. Here‚Äôs how I break it down into a system that builds confidence, clarity, and consistent results:

<<<1. Call Structure Check>>>
--> Did I create rapport?
--> Did I clearly state the goal of the call?
--> Did I confidently ask for the sale/next step?

<<<2. Objection Analysis>>>
--> What objections stumped me today?
--> Which objections used to feel easy but caught me off guard this time?

<<3. Highlight Reel>>
--> What‚Äôs ONE THING I nailed during this call that I want to replicate next time?

This simple reflection process turns every sales call‚Äîwhether a win or a loss‚Äîinto an opportunity to improve.

 What‚Äôs YOUR favorite way to debrief after a call? Let‚Äôs share and grow together.
